Award.AwardTitle: Structure and Deformation in Low-Dimensional Topology
Award.AbstractNarration:
Geometry and topology in two and three dimensions display a particular richness of structure where many different fields of mathematics come together, including classical complex analysis, combinatorial topology, geometry, dynamical systems, and the theory of groups. When three-dimensional spaces (manifolds) are glued together along their two-dimensional boundaries, the properties of the resulting space depend in complex ways on the properties of the gluing maps. The gluing maps themselves form a rich algebraic structure known as a mapping class group; this research project explores a number of settings where this structure comes into play. A particular role is played by a special geometric property of the mapping class group known as relative hyperbolicity, which has enabled the fine geometric structure of three-dimensional manifolds to be teased out and analyzed. Some of the previous advances in this area have yielded general statements but not concrete estimates, and in a number of areas the investigator expects to be able to sharpen current understanding and compute concrete bounds. The focus, nevertheless, is to deepen conceptual understanding of the way that two-dimensional and three-dimensional manifolds fit together.

The project investigates aspects of the interaction between topology of surfaces and three-manifolds, with connections to deformation spaces of geometric structures and geodesic flows in Teichmuller space. A common thread in the work is the hierarchical structure of mapping class groups and the phenomenon of relative hyperbolicity via curve complexes. In a project on fibered hyperbolic three-manifolds, the investigator will explore the "subsurface profiles" of the set of all fibrations, namely the pattern of projections to fiber subsurfaces of the stable and unstable foliations associated to the monodromy maps. The goal here is to obtain uniform (genus independent) descriptions and to relate them to the combinatorial structure of veering triangulations. In Teichmuller theory, the investigator will pursue a conjectural description of the Weil-Petersson geodesic flow on the moduli space of a surface, developing new tools with which to analyze the combinatorial patterns or itineraries of geodesic rays. The investigator will study the skinning map defined by Thurston on the Teichmuller space of the boundary of a hyperbolic three-manifold. He will work toward a better quantitative control of the diameter bounds known for such maps in the acylindrical case. In the general case he will extend previous work that established relative bounded image results, to complete the proof of a claim of Thurston on iterates of the skinning-and-gluing maps in the setting where a gluing yields an atoroidal manifold. This work will also connect to a project on establishing new uniform bi-Lipschitz models for hyperbolic three-manifolds.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project studied a number of aspects of the theory of 3-dimensional manifolds and related topics, especially the way in which geometric, combinatorial and algebraic aspects of the theory interact.

Within a 3-dimensional manifold one often sees intricate 1-dimensional structure, in the sense of flows whose trajectories wind in a complex way throughout the space, and 2-dimensional structure in the sense of foliations or fibrations, in which surfaces stack together like leaves in a fillo dough.  The study of such structures interacts, in ways that are still not completely understood, with the Thurston geometric structures, especially hyperbolic structures, that 3-manifolds can be endowed with.

The study of such phenomena leads to insights into more general aspects of symmetry, especially the study of groups. The symmetry groups that give rise to 3, 2 and 1 dimensional shapes are known as "fundamental groups" in algebraic topology, and these groups turn out to have their own higher-level symmetry groups, called automorphism groups (mapping class groups, in the case of surfaces). The study of these higher level groups as objects in their own right leads to further understanding of symmetry in general.

With M. Landry and S. Taylor, the PI studied what are known as pseudo-Anosov flows in 3-manifolds, and introduced a new algebraic invariant known as a Veering Polynomial, which encodes some of the dynamical properties of such flows, generalizing work of McMullen that applied to fibered 3-manifolds. With B. Modami the PI studied how hyperbolic geometry in a fibered manifold relates to a certain higher-dimensional flow in the space of shapes of the fiber surface, developing some counterexamples to natural conjectures and techniques for further exploring the problem. With C. Leininger, J. Souto and S. Taylor, the PI studied other connections between fibrations of 3-manifolds and the geometry of the space of fiber shapes, generalizing a result of Farb-Leininger-Margalit. With M. Durham and A. Sisto, the PI introduced new methods for analyzing the large-scale structure of the mapping class groups of surfaces, as well as a more general class of groups with similar structure, known as hierarchically hyperbolic groups. With N. Lazarovich and A. Levit, the PI studied the notion of "flexible stability" for fundamental groups of surfaces, which is a kind of error-correcting property motivated by problems in computer science. 

The PI's students, M. Landry, A. Rasmussen and A. Calderon, explored other related aspects of the theory. Landry studied veering triangulations (which relate to the work on polynomials mentioned above). Rasmussen studied a number of generalizations of mapping class groups and the overall problem of coarse geometry of groups and their actions on hyperbolic spaces. Calderon studied flows and group actions in the space of shapes of flat surfaces, which are related to the dynamics of billiards. 

The grant also funded a continuation of the PI's outreach program, Math Mornings, which provides mathematics lectures and activities for the public in New Haven, Connecticut.
